newsitem.title: USA: NASA says no decision yet on Mir spacewalk.
newsitem.headline: NASA says no decision yet on Mir spacewalk.

text.p: NASA officials have made no final decision on a Russian proposal to send U.S. astronaut Michael Foale on a spacewalk to inspect Mir's damaged compartment, a spokesman said on Thursday.

The U.S. space agency was caught off guard when Russian flight director Vladimir Solovyov told reporters in Moscow on Thursday that Foale would be making a Sept. 3 spacewalk to inspect the Spektr module rammed by an errant cargo craft.
"No decision has been made regarding Foale's participation in the Sept. 3 spacewalk," NASA spokesman Rob Navias said.
The involvement of Americans in spacewalks from Mir has been under discussion for weeks, he said.
Navias said he had no idea why the Russians would want Foale to participate in that particular spacewalk.
It had been expected that Russian cosmonauts Anatoly Solovyev and Pavel Vinogradov would make the spacewalk to locate the breach in the module's air-tight hull.
Navias said there were no discussions about Foale assisting in an internal spacewalk planned for Aug. 20 to restore some of the electrical power lost in the orbital collision.
NASA announced last week it was dropping astronaut Wendy Lawrence from the next Mir mission because she was too short to fit into a space suit if she was called upon to help in a spacewalk.
Lawrence's place was taken by David Wolf, who is undergoing a crash course in Russian spacewalking. Foale, who has lived aboard Mir since May, will be relieved by Wolf in September or October.
